pr_title: Introduce Sinks and deprecate concrete processors

timeline.message: wip first round of deprecation fixes for tests

timeline.bodyText: Can these wait until a major to be removed?
timeline.author: spencergibb
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -77,7 +78,9 @@ *

* * @param the input and output value type + * @deprecated Prefer clear cut usage of either {@link Processors} or {@link Sinks}, to be removed in 3.5

replies.bodyText: can you expand on your concern ? if we follow the history of Reactor (2.x > 3.0 > 3.1 > 3.2 and now 3.3), a "major" would be a significant event that would probably mean a complete re-architecture, to the point that the whole ecosystem around Reactor would probably need heavy re-architecturing too, or break (see Reactor 2 vs Reactor 3). The only other drives for a Reactor 4 that I could think about are a change in the Java baseline or the advent of a Reactive Streams v2. In any case, very unlikely at this point.
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: deprecating one release and removing the next just breaks backward compatibility quickly. With boot moving to a 6-month cadence for minors, they are deprecating, then waiting an extra release to remove. So deprecate in x.1, do nothing in x.2 and remove in x.3.
replies.author: spencergibb

replies.bodyText: I see. But unlike Boot, we haven't switched to a 6 month cadence. So deprecating these now would mean that the concrete classes would disappear from the public API in a year or so. Initially, there was an issue to directly remove them without the deprecation, but I agree this would be overkill. Note that TopicProcessor and WorkQueueProcessor are slated to be removed though (since deprecated in 3.3.0)
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: 👍 got it. thanks for taking the time to explain.
replies.author: spencergibb

timeline.message:
Introduce FluxSink superinterface, Sinks vs Processors...

Also deprecate FluxProcessor concrete implementations.
Fix compilation of prod+test; fix warnings in prod
Update guide to use Sinks.hotFlux instead of DirectProcessor
wip first round of deprecation fixes for tests
Fixup UnicastProcessor initial request
Have UnicastProcessor expose ACTUAL attribute
Replace processor with standalone sink in FluxBufferTimeoutTest
Remove deprecated uses of concrete processors in flux tests
Remove deprecated uses of concrete processors in reactor-test tests
Remove deprecated uses of concrete processors in BaseOperatorTest

SinkFlux to SequenceSink, add ScalarSink, add more flavors

TODO test latest() and trigger() mono-like sinks.
Align Processors size replay method naming with Sinks
Remove SequenceToMonoSink, polish
polish unicast() sink and test
Add documentation around standalone sinks
Add documentation around standalone sinks
polish asciidoc and fix issues
Swap multicast() and multicastPreWarming, buffer by defaut
Align multicastReplay Sinks naming with replay Processors

timeline.bodyText:
Since asFlux() exposes Flux<T> but not concrete Processor onEachOperator hook could be applied here.
Since FluxProcessors are ASYNC Publishers it could help with Thread context propagations
timeline.author: robotmrv
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,262 @@ +/* + * Copyright (c) 2011-Present VMware Inc. or its affiliates, All Rights Reserved. + * + * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); + * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. + * You may obtain a copy of the License at + * + * https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 + * + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software + * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and + * limitations under the License. + */ + +package reactor.core.publisher; + +import org.reactivestreams.Subscriber; + +import reactor.util.annotation.Nullable; +import reactor.util.concurrent.Queues; +import reactor.util.context.Context; + +/** + * A collection of standalone sinks ({@link StandaloneFluxSink} and + * {@link StandaloneMonoSink}). + * + * @author Simon Baslé + */ +public final class Sinks { + + private Sinks() { } + + /** + * A {@link StandaloneFluxSink} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Backpressure : this sink honors downstream demand by conforming to the lowest demand in case + * of multiple subscribers.
    • + *
  • Replaying: No replay. Only forwards to a {@link Subscriber} the elements that have been + * pushed to the sink AFTER this subscriber was subscribed. To the exception of the first + * subscriber (see below).
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: warm up. Remembers up to {@link Queues#SMALL_BUFFER_SIZE} + * elements pushed before the first {@link Subscriber} is registered.
    • + *
+ */ + @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") + public static StandaloneFluxSink multicast() { + return new FluxProcessorSink<>(EmitterProcessor.create(Queues.SMALL_BUFFER_SIZE)); + } + + /** + * A {@link StandaloneFluxSink} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Backpressure : this sink honors downstream demand of individual subscribers.
    • + *
  • Replaying: No replay. Only forwards to a {@link Subscriber} the elements that have been + * pushed to the sink AFTER this subscriber was subscribed.
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: Discarding. Pushing elements while there are no {@link Subscriber} + * registered will simply discard these elements instead of "warming up" the sink.
    • + *
+ */ + @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") + public static StandaloneFluxSink multicastNoWarmup() { + return new FluxProcessorSink<>(ReplayProcessor.create(0)); + } + + /** + * A {@link StandaloneFluxSink} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Backpressure : this sink honors downstream demand of individual subscribers.
    • + *
  • Replaying: by {@code historySize}. Keeps the last {@code historySize} elements and + * replays them instantly to new subscribers before continuing with "live" elements.
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: buffers enough elements pushed without a subscriber to + * honor the {@code historySize}.
    • + *
+ */ + @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") + public static StandaloneFluxSink replay(int historySize) { + return new FluxProcessorSink<>(ReplayProcessor.create(historySize)); + } + + /** + * A {@link StandaloneFluxSink} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Backpressure : this sink honors downstream demand of individual subscribers.
    • + *
  • Replaying: all elements pushed to this sink are replayed to new subscribers.
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: all elements pushed to this sink are remembered, + * even when there is no subscriber.
    • + *
+ */ + @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") + public static StandaloneFluxSink replayAll() { + return new FluxProcessorSink<>(ReplayProcessor.create()); + } + + /** + * A {@link StandaloneFluxSink} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Unicast: contrary to most other {@link StandaloneFluxSink}, the + * {@link Flux} view rejects {@link Subscriber subscribers} past the first one.
    • + *
  • Backpressure : this sink honors downstream demand of its single {@link Subscriber}.
    • + *
  • Replaying: non-applicable, since only one {@link Subscriber} can register.
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: all elements pushed to this sink are remembered and will + * be replayed once the {@link Subscriber} subscribes.
    • + *
+ */ + @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") + public static StandaloneFluxSink unicast() { + return new FluxProcessorSink<>(UnicastProcessor.create()); + } + + /** + * A {@link StandaloneMonoSink} that can be triggered at any time by either of + * the three completions: {@link ScalarSink#success(Object) valued completion}, + * {@link ScalarSink#success() empty completions} or {@link ScalarSink#error(Throwable) error}. + * This completion is replayed to late subscribers. + */ + public static StandaloneMonoSink trigger() { + return new MonoProcessorSink<>(MonoProcessor.create()); + } + + // == interfaces == + + /** + * A flavor of {@link SequenceSink} that is not attached to a single {@link Subscriber} + * but rather viewable {@link #asFlux() as a Flux}. Most likely, such a {@link SequenceSink} + * is capable of multicasting to several subscribers. However implementations can chose + * to be unicast instead, and only accept one {@link Subscriber} at a time (as allowed + * by the {@link org.reactivestreams.Publisher} specification). + * + * @param the type of elements that can be emitted through this sink + */ + public interface StandaloneFluxSink extends SequenceSink { + + @Override + StandaloneFluxSink next(T t); + + /** + * Return the companion {@link Flux} instance that is backed by this sink. + * All calls to this method return the same instance. + * + * @return the {@link Flux} view associated to this {@link StandaloneFluxSink} + */ + Flux asFlux(); + + } + + /** + * A flavor of {@link ScalarSink} that is not attached to a single {@link Subscriber} + * but rather viewable {@link #asMono() as a Mono}. Most likely, such a {@link ScalarSink} + * is capable of multicasting to several subscribers. However implementations can chose + * to be unicast instead, and only accept one {@link Subscriber} at a time (as allowed + * by the {@link org.reactivestreams.Publisher} specification). + * + * @param the type of elements that can be emitted through this sink + */ + public interface StandaloneMonoSink extends ScalarSink { + + /** + * Return the companion {@link Mono} instance that is backed by this sink. + * All calls to this method return the same instance. + * + * @return the {@link Mono} view associated to this {@link StandaloneMonoSink} + */ + Mono asMono(); + } + + // == concrete classes == + + static final class FluxProcessorSink + implements StandaloneFluxSink { + + final FluxSink delegateSink; + final FluxProcessor processor; + + @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") + FluxProcessorSink(FluxProcessor processor) { + this.processor = processor; + this.delegateSink = processor.sink(); + } + + @Override + public Flux asFlux() { + return processor;

replies.bodyText: the processor in question is only fed via manual interactions, so I'm not sure how that would help eg. if the user decides to do a new Thread(() -> sink.next(1)).start()...
replies.author: simonbasle
robotmrv

replies.bodyText: I need to look deeper into the consequences of that, not sure applying the hooks to the processor will work naturally. plus currently there is no such thing with processors. can you chime back in once M1 is released (eg creating an issue for M2) ?
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: the javadoc is automatically copied, inheritDoc is only if you want to supplement it with additional content while including the super content
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.bodyText:
FYI one of the reasons why I was choosing concrete type over FluxProcessor is because having to specify the type argument twice was a bit cumbersome.
As this is a new API, perhaps we can do something about it? especially given that now it is always <T, T>
timeline.author: bsideup
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,143 @@

+package reactor.core.publisher;
+
+import java.time.Duration;
+import java.util.Queue;
+import java.util.function.Consumer;
+
+import reactor.core.Disposable;
+import reactor.core.scheduler.Scheduler;
+import reactor.util.annotation.Nullable;
+
+/**
+ * @author Simon Baslé
+ */
+public final class Processors {
+
+
+	@SuppressWarnings("deprecation")
+	public static final <T> FluxProcessor<T, T> unicast() {

replies.bodyText:
the number of new interfaces / classes was a concern in the original proposal back then, but there's probably little way around the current split into 4 sink interfaces (plus 2 additional utility classes).
we could improve that <T,T> situation but it means adding FluxIdentityProcessor<T> at least... Maybe Processors can be turned into both interface and factory.
It raises another issue, which is the misalignment between FluxProcessor<A,B> and MonoProcessor<A> (mono processor has a single concrete implementation, and thus doesn't help with representing processing stages). That'll be a concern for either M2 or 3.5 now :/
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText:
actually it cannot be melded with Processors, the FluxProcessor being an abstract class (due to the need to extend Flux)... furthermore replay factory method on Processors would clash with Flux#replay(), and the factory methods would be lost in the noise of Flux API.
Instead I went ahead and added an abstract intermediate FluxIdentityProcessor<T> extends FluxProcessor<T, T>
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.bodyText:
"warmup" sounds like a new term added. And, TBH, I struggle to understand it (even after reading the javadoc) 😅
Could you please help me understanding the concept?
timeline.author: bsideup
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,262 @@ +/* + * Copyright (c) 2011-Present VMware Inc. or its affiliates, All Rights Reserved. + * + * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); + * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. + * You may obtain a copy of the License at + * + * https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 + * + * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software + * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, + * WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. + * See the License for the specific language governing permissions and + * limitations under the License. + */ + +package reactor.core.publisher; + +import org.reactivestreams.Subscriber; + +import reactor.util.annotation.Nullable; +import reactor.util.concurrent.Queues; +import reactor.util.context.Context; + +/** + * A collection of standalone sinks ({@link StandaloneFluxSink} and + * {@link StandaloneMonoSink}). + * + * @author Simon Baslé + */ +public final class Sinks { + + private Sinks() { } + + /** + * A {@link StandaloneFluxSink} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Backpressure : this sink honors downstream demand by conforming to the lowest demand in case + * of multiple subscribers.
    • + *
  • Replaying: No replay. Only forwards to a {@link Subscriber} the elements that have been + * pushed to the sink AFTER this subscriber was subscribed. To the exception of the first + * subscriber (see below).
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: warm up. Remembers up to {@link Queues#SMALL_BUFFER_SIZE} + * elements pushed before the first {@link Subscriber} is registered.
    • + *
+ */ + @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") + public static StandaloneFluxSink multicast() { + return new FluxProcessorSink<>(EmitterProcessor.create(Queues.SMALL_BUFFER_SIZE)); + } + + /** + * A {@link StandaloneFluxSink} with the following characteristics: + *
    + *
  • Multicast
    • + *
  • Backpressure : this sink honors downstream demand of individual subscribers.
    • + *
  • Replaying: No replay. Only forwards to a {@link Subscriber} the elements that have been + * pushed to the sink AFTER this subscriber was subscribed.
    • + *
  • Without {@link Subscriber}: Discarding. Pushing elements while there are no {@link Subscriber} + * registered will simply discard these elements instead of "warming up" the sink.
    • + *
+ */ + @SuppressWarnings("deprecation") + public static StandaloneFluxSink multicastNoWarmup() {

replies.bodyText:
yeah I'm having trouble finding a better term. It's the way some processors will "remember" upstream onNext (or in our case sink.next) that come in BEFORE the first Subscriber subscribes. But then the second Subscriber would only see live pushes.
\ denotes a subscription
<-warmup------><---------hot ---------->

--(1)---(2)----\---------\----(3)------>   sink
              -\(1)(2)--------(3)------>   sub1
                        -\----(3)------>   sub2
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: Thanks, the diagram really helps! Maybe let's add it to the javadoc?
replies.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText: I'll add a quick SVG version for both multicast() and multicastNoWarmup()
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: I don't really like trigger either, future and promise sound too overloaded. Maybe completable to echo both CompletableFuture and Completable in RxJava? By I fear this becomes overloaded too...
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: IIRC Completable in RxJava is Publisher<Void>. It does sound too overloaded but we're talking about method's name, not type, so I think we're fine as it helps understanding the return value much better.
replies.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText: ok, I'll go with promise actually...
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.bodyText: Just curious, why not using CAS?
timeline.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText: too much on my plate to have the perfect implementation in time for M1 :(

timeline.message: Rework SinksTests to mutualize code as dynamic tests
per review, improve javadocs and add svg for warmup concept
per review, rename trigger to promise. add tests and fix error drop
Add FluxIdentityProcessor<T> specialization of FluxProcessor<T,T>
fixup compilation and some additional deprecation warnings
fixup hanging test
Switch from FluxProcessor<T,T> to FluxIdentityProcessor<T> in operators
